intro: Rubus thyrsoideus var. subhispidulus, commonly known as the prickly rose or thorny blackberry, is a perennial shrub native to the eastern United States. It features compound leaves with serrated edges and small, thorned stems that provide structural support. The plant produces aggregate fruits composed of tiny, dark red to black drupelets. Its flowers are typically white or pale pink, with five petals and numerous stamens. It thrives in woodland edges and moist soils, showing adaptability to partial shade and varying moisture conditions.
